prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together. The author pays all the bills and rent because the girlfriend only works part-time. Then there was an incident where the author didn't have their wallet and asked the girlfriend to pay for takeout, which was under $40. The girlfriend's reaction was negative, and now the author is considering making her pay some bills because of this one incident.

First, I need to look at both sides. The author might feel that since the girlfriend isn't contributing financially, even a small amount, it's unfair. The girlfriend works part-time, which might mean her income is lower, but maybe she has other expenses or contributes in non-monetary ways. The author is upset because of the girlfriend's attitude during the takeout incident. The author might feel that the girlfriend is taking things for granted, especially since they pay everything. But is it fair to make her start paying bills because of one incident?

The key points here include the financial arrangement, communication between the couple, and expectations. The author hasn't mentioned discussing financial responsibilities before. Maybe the girlfriend didn't realize that she should be contributing, or perhaps there was an unspoken understanding. The author is now upset about the takeout payment, which could indicate a deeper issue about fairness and contribution. However, making her pay more bills after one incident might be a harsh reaction. It's possible the author is overreacting because of the emotional response to the girlfriend's reaction, rather than addressing the underlying issue of shared responsibilities. The author might be in the wrong if they haven't communicated their expectations clearly and are now punishing the girlfriend for an isolated event. Alternatively, if the author feels the girlfriend isn't contributing enough, it's reasonable to discuss splitting costs, but doing it over a single incident might be unfair. The answer depends on whether the author's reaction is proportionate and if they've had prior discussions about financial responsibilities.
